questions.text: A 25-YEAR-OLD woman presents with a 6-month history of amenorrhea, weight gain, and acne. Her pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is consistent with the most likely disorder in her?

options.label: D
options.text: A history of regular menses each month prior to6 months

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endometrial hyperplasia

Highyeild:

Endometrial Hyperplasia It represents a spectrum of morphological and biological alteration of the endometrium (both in glands and stroma), ranging from an exaggerated physiological state to carcinoma in situ. They are clinically important because: They cause abnormal bleeding. Either precede or occur simultaneously with endometrial carcinoma. Premalignant Lesions of Endometrium are: Simple hyperplasia : Endometrium is thick. The glands are dilated and have outpouching and invaginations. They are crowded and have irregular outlines. The stroma is more dense and cellular. Complex hyperplasia : Endometrium is thicker. The gland are crowded and arranged back to back with reduced stroma. Most glands have irregular outlines. There are papillary processes and intraluminal bridges within the glands. Epithelial pseudo stratification is present. Premenopausal women : Progesterone therapy- Medroxyprogesterone acetate for 21 days a month daily for 3 months. or Progesterone containing IUCD. Post menopausal women: Simple hyperplasia without atypia–generally followed without therapy. Complex hyperplasia without atypia– cyclical/continuous progesterone therapy. These patients should be followed annually by endometrial biopsy. Atypical hyperplasia : The endometrial glands have cytologic atypia. The gland outlines are of complex hyperplasia in type. The nuclei of the glands show enlargement, irregular size and shape, hyperchromasia and coarse chromatin. In this category chances of malignancy are high ( simple-8%, complex-30%, hence they are managed surgically). The ideal treatment is– Hysterectomy Premenopausal women willing to preserve fertility: High dose progesterone therapy after full information of the risk of undiagnosed cancer or progression to cancer. In these cases periodic TVS a nd endometrial biopsy i s necessary. Carcinoma-in-situ : Commonly describes a lesion with severe cytologic as well as architectural abnormalities of the glands.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B: Osteoporosis is a risk in hypoestrogenic states, and this patient has estrogen excess, so osteoporosis is not a concern Option A: Vaginal atrophy is associated with estrogen deficiency, not excess. Option D: Glucose intolerance, diabetes mellitus, and a history of oligomenorrhea since menarche are consistent with the diagnosis of PCOS.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is noted to be taking tamoxifen to help with breast cancer. Now she complains of increased menstrual flow and intermenstrual bleeding. What may be the probable reason for her uterine bleed?

options.label: A
options.text: Tamoxifen has an agonist effect on the uterus, thereby leading to endometrial hyperplasia.

options.label: B
options.text: Tamoxifen is an estrogen antagonist in the uterus, leading to endometrial atrophy

options.label: C
options.text: The increased endometrial bleed has nothing to do with Tamoxifen

options.label: D
options.text: The breast cancer might have metastasized to the uterus presenting with increased bleed

questions.correct_answer: A. Tamoxifen has an agonist effect on the uterus, thereby leading to endometrial hyperplasia.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tamoxifen has an agonist effect on the uterus, thereby leading to endometrial hyperplasia.

Highyeild:

Tamoxifen is a SERM that has antagonistic effects on the And so used for the treatment of breast carcinoma. But it has agonistic effects on Uterus, lipid profile, bones, and clotting factors. The agonistic effect in the uterus may lead to endometrial hyperplasia and even endometrial cancers. Malignancies caused by long-term tamoxifen therapy: Carcinoma endometrium -it is the most common carcinoma associated with it. Uterine sarcoma. Rare liver cancer with long-term high doses.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

Extraedge:

Non-malignant effects of tamoxifen on the uterus: Endometrial hyperplasia Endometriosis Fibroid uterus Ovarian cysts Menstrual irregularities or amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding. On USG examination endometrial thickness is 19mm. What is your next step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endometrial biopsy As the patient presents with Heavy bleeding and the first investigation is done i.e., TVS showing endometrial thickness 19 mm. so, the Next investigation to be performed is ENDOMETRIAL BIOPSY .

Highyeild:

INVESTIGATIONS IN CASE OF ENDOMETRIAL CANCER : TVS It is the 1st step taken in women who present with post-menopausal bleeding to decide whether endometrial sampling is needed or not. If endometrial thickness is less than 4 mm, further testing may be deferred. But if there is a recurrence of bleeding, a tissue diagnosis is essential. Other factors to be assessed are the presence of a polypoidal endometrial mass or fluid collection as the latter may indicate pyometra. Endometrial Sampling This could be done by any of the following methods- Office endometrial aspiration biopsy Traditional fractional curettage Hysteroscopy and directed biopsy. Endometrial Aspiration Biopsy It is the IOC for endometrial cancer. Diagnostic accuracy: 92-98% Endometrial aspiration biopsy can be performed in the outpatient setting as it does not require any anesthesia and has the advantage of being simple, quick, safe, inexpensive, and convenient. It is combined with endocervical curettage to rule out cancer cervix. It is done using a vibra aspirator, Sharman curette, or Pipelle endometrial sampler (Fig. 14A.2). Fractional Curettage Fractional curettage is the Gold standard investigation used for ruling out endometrial cancer Here the endocervical canal is curreted first followed by dilation and endometrial curettage. Indications: Cervical stenosis; If clinical suspicion of malignancy is high; If bleeding recurs after a negative report on endometrial aspiration. Hysteroscopy and Biopsy It is not recommended routinely for endometrial cancer as most of the cancers are detected easily by endometrial aspiration biopsy and hysteroscopy is good for focal lesions. Pap Smear It is not a reliable test for diagnosis of Endometrial carcinoma. Only 30-50% of patients with endometrial carcinoma have positive pap tests and they are women with advanced disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option C: done if the sample shows atypia Option D: done if the sample doesn't show atypia Option B: indicated if malignancy is suspected

questions.text: The following is the image of a woman who presents with you with infertility and who has used tamoxifen for breast cancer. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endometrial polyp

Highyeild:

Endometrial polyp: An endometrial polyp or uterine polyp is an abnormal growth containing glands, stroma, and blood vessels projecting from the lining of the uterus (endometrium) that occupies spaces small or large enough to fill the uterine cavity. They are found during both reproductive and postmenopausal phases of life. USG shows homogeneous isoechoic to and continuous with the endometrium and preserves the endometrial interface. Color Doppler shows a "feeding vessel sign" - suggestive of the endometrial polyp. Treatment Asymptomatic woman: observation and follow up Symptomatic woman: surgical removal IMAGES OF ENDOMETRIAL POLYP. Op tion A,C, and D: are incorrect options.
